title: Can anyone concisely explain Heidegger's 'waiting' from his later philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: I imagine you mean ‘waiting’ in terms of the concept of Gelassenheit, right? You might find this piece by Barbara Pezze useful, though it’s not particularly concise… Speaking generally, Heidegger is concerned with the nature of thinking. He starts off critiquing what he calls “calculative thinking”: goal-oriented, mechanistic, concrete, active thinking; the thinking of a scientist, or an academic, or a businessman (or really, of most of us in most of our daily lives). This form of thinking, for Heidegger, is ultimately sterile; it collapses to and enslaves us under technos (my term for the forms and systems of technology/bureaucracy; the reduction of human life to a set of calculations and measurements). Someone sets their eye on a particular goal (be it a job, or a house, or a car, or a lover), does the steps necessary to achieve it; sets their eye on another goal, does the steps; sets their eye on another goal… an entire life might be lived that way with the mechanical precision of a robot. If one wants to call that a life… He goes on to suggest that what we are really after is Gelassenheit (the essence of thinking, or meditative thinking). Where calculative thinking is action-based, meditative thinking is thought without action. To quote the article I linked above: If calculative thinking does not think beyond the usefulness of what it engages with, meditative thinking would notice and become aware of the fact that these devices are not just extremely useful to us. It would also notice that they, by being so extremely useful, at the same time are “shackling” us: “suddenly and unaware we find ourselves so firmly shackled to these technical devices that we fall into bondage to them” (ibid., p. 53-54). If man, not being aware of this, is in a situation of being chained to these machineries, then by becoming conscious of this he finds himself in a different relation to them. He becomes free of them. With this awareness man can utilize these instruments just as instruments, being at the same time free to “let go of them at any time” (ibid., p. 54). And this is so because once we acknowledge that their usefulness implies the possibility for us to be chained to them, we deal with them differently; we “deny them the right to dominate us, and so to wrap, confuse, and lay waste our nature” (ibid., p.54). It is a matter of a different comportment towards them; it is a different disposition to which Heidegger gives the name “releasement toward things” [die Gelassenheit zu den Dingen] (ibid., p.54) In other words, we can use a tool like an iPhone to do all sorts of things (that’s normal calculative thinking), but unless we can step back and see our relationship to the tool — step back and see, for instance, how much of our lives we spend on Quora or Facebook; see what urges and drives bring us to spend our time that way — we are simply slaves to the tool. Now, Gelassenheit is undefined (and probably indefinable); we don’t know what the essence of thinking (non-active, meditative thinking) is. But waiting is the doorway to it. Waiting is the most obvious and salient form of non-active engagement; it is (so to speak) the action that leads us to non-action. We don’t want to wait for something; that is an active (calculative) mindset that is looking for a particular thing to come down the pike. We simply want to wait, which is neither an end in itself nor a means to any particular end. Heidegger is converging on Eastern mysticism here, and there is a whole lot I could say from that perspective. But I think this covers it in a nutshell.
